[@dangerousbeans](@TXKFQehlyoSn8UJAIVP/k2BjFINC591MlBC2e2d24mA=.ed25519) [@jacob](@Vz6v3xKpzViiTM/GAe+hKkACZSqrErQQZgv4iqQxEn8=.ed25519) 

Yeah, it's trivial to auto-linkify a valid URI (e.g. dat://colorclock.hashbase.io) but Dat identifiers have a conflict with the URI specification:

- They use `://` which denotes that the following bit is a **location**, which it isn't (it's a public key)
- Any URI parser that sees a location will ensure that it's a valid host
- Hosts segments (domains, subdomains, ...) may only have a length of 63 characters
- The public key has a length of 64 characters, which means it's not a valid URI and is left alone

The solution is simple but probably tedious: Dat identifiers should start with `dat:` rather than `dat://`, which removes the 63-character limit and fixes the semantics around the public key. I've opened [an issue about this problem](https://github.com/datproject/dat/issues/1050) but it doesn't sound like the Dat team has the bandwidth for this right now (which I can absolutely empathize with).

If you want to make a link to a Dat public key, you'll need to wrap it with `<` and `>`:

```md
<dat://2b23c5ac0842a9558fea6f96e33078610e254dd599d295a5b93faad629693992>
```

Example: <dat://2b23c5ac0842a9558fea6f96e33078610e254dd599d295a5b93faad629693992>
